Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Species limits, hybrid zones, and systematics of the North American turtle genus Sternotherus
Award.AbstractNarration:
Biodiversity is typically measured by counting the number of species in an area and the conservation status of species is assessed through periodic inventories to measure gain or loss of species over time. However modern science has discovered the prevalence of cryptic species. These are species that have few or no obvious morphological distinguishing features, which traditionally define species, but do not interbreed and therefore are separate biological species. New genetic technologies can identify cryptic species and provide important tools to more accurately measure biodiversity. The southeastern United States, especially Alabama, is a hotspot of aquatic biodiversity, especially for turtles. The North American turtle genus, Sternotherus, diversity has been under-described taxonomically relative to other turtle lineages due to morphological conservatism between and within species This project will investigate the morphology and genetics of Sternotherus to identify cryptic diversity and the evolutionary relationships among taxa. These data can be used to make evidence based conservation planning decisions which can optimize the use of funding to protect and conserve biodiversity. While accomplishing the project goals, undergraduate students will be mentored in a variety of biological sub-disciplines including field ecology, molecular biology, and bioinformatics. Effort will be made to include students underrepresented in STEM fields as well as Alabama natives.

The research project will test species limits and infer relationships within a poorly resolved and imperiled turtle genus: Sternotherus. Sternotherus currently consists of four species for which past studies have presented conflicting relationships. This calls into question the taxonomic validity of some species and suggests that other populations are cryptic taxa. The researchers will collect samples from turtles across their entire distribution in the southeastern United States. These turtles will be measured for many morphological characters including shape and size. The researchers will perform genetic analyses using mtDNA and RAD-tag sequencing on the turtle DNA. This research takes an integrative approach considering gene history and hybridization for identifying species and species relationships within Sternotherus. These data will be used to test 1) genus wide species limits; 2) the role of hybridization between species; and, 3) species-level relationships within this group of turtles. This integrative analytical approach will resolve taxonomic relationships as well as identify incomplete lineage sorting, rapid radiations, and low level gene flow which confounded genetic signal in previous work

POR.DRECONTENT:
Accurate and consistent delimitation of species and their relationships provide a necessary framework for comparative studies, understanding evolutionary relationships, and informing conservation management decisions. Despite the ever-increasing availability of genomic data, evolutionary dynamics can still render some relationships exceedingly difficult to resolve, including underlying speciation events that are rapid, recent, or confounded by post-speciation introgression. To advance our understanding of the use of species delimitation methods in the some of the most difficult natural biological scenarios, we sought to reassess our taxonomic understanding of North American musk turtles (Sternotherus). This group of turtles is very interesting as they have: 1) suffered from a turbulent taxonomic history, where species limits and relationships have been poorly resolved; 2) are known to hybridize in natural settings; and, 3) have one species (the flattened musk turtle) that is critically endangered.

To accurately and robustly reassess the systematics of musk turtles, we combined dense geographic sampling with reduced representation genetic sequencing to gather 1000’s of independent loci for all sequenced individuals. We successfully trapped over 400 unique turtles, which were marked, sampled, and returned to site of capture. We then sequenced >200 individuals for 4500 loci, allowing for near-comprehensive geographic and in-depth genomic assessment of this genus. This work resulted in an improved understanding of species-limits in this genus which resulted in the elevation of two formally described subspecies and description of a new species; thus, brining species level diversity from four to six species. We also used systematics and demographic modeling (which can now be applied to many other similar systems) to understand how these species are related to each other and better inform hypotheses of speciation in aquatic systems across the southeastern United States.

Additionally, we examined the genomic architecture of a hybrid zone between two musk turtle species. This analysis provided evidence that hybridization between these two species (one newly described above) was likely caused by anthropogenic alteration to natural riverine habitat though building of lock and dam systems. We have been able to infer that natural genomic incompatibilities impede hybridization in the expected direction of river flow, thus offering valuable insights into what it means to be a species in this, and potentially other, systems. Lastly, we show that anthropogenically-mediated hybridization is occurring in the direction opposite of river flow into the imperiled flattened musk turtle. This information can potentially be used to reassess the status of this species and provides actionable targets for limiting further introgression which can be used to aid conservation management planning to protect this species.
